svmodt 0.1.0
  • Reference

    • Constructing Oblique Trees with svmodt

    Build a Decision Tree with Cost-Complexity Pruning

    generate_tree.Rd

    Constructs a decision tree for classification using a chosen splitting criterion (Gini impurity, information gain, or gain ratio). Supports numeric and factor features and integrates cost–complexity pruning via an alpha parameter.

    generate_tree(
  target,
  features,
  criteria_type = c("gini", "info_gain", "gain_ratio"),
  ig_metric = c("gini", "entropy"),
  depth = 1,
  max_depth = 10,
  all_levels = NULL,
  alpha = 0
)

    Arguments

    target

    A vector of class labels (factor or character) for the samples.

    features

    A data frame or matrix of predictor variables.

    criteria_type

    Splitting criterion: "gini", "info_gain", or "gain_ratio".

    ig_metric

    Impurity metric to use for info_gain: "gini" or "entropy".

    depth

    Internal use: current recursion depth (default = 1).

    max_depth

    Maximum allowed depth of the tree (default = 10).

    all_levels

    Optional vector of all possible class levels. If NULL, inferred from target.

    alpha

    Cost-complexity pruning parameter. Higher values increase pruning (default = 0).

    Value

    A nested list representing the decision tree. Each node contains:

    • split_feature: Name of the feature used for splitting (internal nodes only).

    • split_value: Numeric threshold or factor level used for splitting (internal nodes only).

    • left: Left child subtree (samples satisfying the split condition).

    • right: Right child subtree.

    • probs: Named vector of class probabilities at the node.

    • prediction: Majority class at the node.

    • n: Number of samples at the node.

    Details

    The function recursively grows a classification tree:

    • Stops if maximum depth is reached, or if the node is pure (all samples belong to one class).

    • Selects the best feature and split point using the chosen criteria_type.

    • Handles numeric and factor features automatically.

    • Implements cost–complexity pruning: compares subtree error with leaf error, scaled by alpha.

    • Returns a leaf node if no valid split exists or if pruning criterion favors collapsing the node.

    Examples

    # Example with wdbc dataset
data(wdbc)
features <- wdbc[, 2:31]
target <- wdbc$diagnosis
tree <- generate_tree(target, features, criteria_type = "gini", max_depth = 3, alpha = 0.01)

# Access root node prediction
tree$prediction
#> [1] "B"

# Access left child subtree
tree$left
#> $split_feature
#> [1] "concave.points_worst"
#> 
#> $split_value
#> [1] 0.1358
#> 
#> $left
#> $left$prediction
#> [1] "B"
#> 
#> $left$probs
#>          B          M 
#> 0.98498498 0.01501502 
#> 
#> $left$n
#> [1] 333
#> 
#> 
#> $right
#> $right$prediction
#> [1] "M"
#> 
#> $right$probs
#>         B         M 
#> 0.3913043 0.6086957 
#> 
#> $right$n
#> [1] 46
#> 
#> 
#> $probs
#>          B          M 
#> 0.91292876 0.08707124 
#> 
#> $prediction
#> [1] "B"
#> 
#> $n
#> [1] 379
#>
